properties.name: BAS004
properties.notes: The regeneration of Basing View is being actively pursued by the borough council. This is reflected in Local Plan policy SS8 which supports the redevelopment of the area for a mix of uses including a residential component of approximately 300 units. The site is in a suitable location for housing development, lying in a highly accessible location with good access to public transport interchanges, town centre facilities and employment opportunities. The Council has recently published the Basing View Masterplan which includes provision for residential development. The site plan shows the whole of basing view reflecting the local plan allocation. The precise location of the residential element will be determined through site masterplanning.
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS009
properties.notes: The site has been promoted for development through the council's Call for Sites in 2019 and the council consider this site to be potentially developable for 300 dwellings within a 5-9 year time period
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority
properties.site-address: Festival Place Hampstead House Kensington House Chelsea House and Westminster House Basingstoke

properties.name: BAS012
properties.notes: The site is a SHELAA site (BAS012) which falls within the built up area of Basingstoke and within the SPB in an area of predominantly residential development in close proximity to the town. The current use as a police station is due to cease (as part of the wider review of Hampshire Constabulary sites) and the site is currently being marketed for redevelopment. An applicaton was submited in Feburary 2019 (19/00436/FUL) for 55 retirements apartments. The application was refused and turned away at appeal due to insufficient information to validate. Another application for 56 returment appartments (19/01822/FUL was refused in February 2020 with an appeal lodged in March 2020.
properties.ownership-status: not owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS024
properties.notes: The site has been promoted for development through the council's Call for Sites in 2019. An application for 89 dwellings was refused at appeal in 2020 (19/01110/OUT). It is unclear whether the site is deliverable so has been removed from the BLR
properties.ownership-status: not owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS026

A planning application has been submitted and is at an advanced stage (17/04029/FUL). The council has accepted, through a previous planning application on the site, that the loss of a care facility is acceptable in planning terms. The re-use of the site for residential development is therefore established. The site is deliverable within five years.. Residential development of 12 units. http:www.basingstoke.gov.uk/SHELAA
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS031
properties.notes: Consent was originally granted on the wider site for the demolition of the Former Newman Bassett House building and a replacement smaller ‘respite unit’ which has now been completed. (Hindson House).Therefore, this retains the facility and service use and frees up the remainder of the land for residential redevelopment. The land is vacant but not currently available as it is being used as a temporary construction compound, the requirement for which is due to cease in late 2018. Afterwhich HCC confirm that they intend to apply for planning permission for residential development.
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority
properties.site-address: Land At Former Newman Bassett House Basingstoke

properties.name: BAS032
properties.notes: The site has been promoted for development through the council's Call for Sites in 2019 by HCC and the council consider this site to be potentially developable for 18 dwellings within a 5-9 year time period
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS043
properties.notes: The SHELAA site (BAS043) benefits from planning permission granted in July 2018 (18/01270/FUL) for 10 units. The agent has confirmed that the development is well advanced and completions are expected in 2018/19. The site is deliverable within five years.. Residential development of 10 units. http:www.basingstoke.gov.uk/SHELAA
properties.ownership-status: not owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS045
properties.notes: Planning permission for the conversion of this council owned building was granted in October 2014 (14/00759/FUL). This permission lapsed in 2018 and a new permission was granted in September 2018 (17/04259/FUL). Work is expected to commence in 2018-19. The site is deliverable within five years.. Change of use from offices to 10 residential affordable units and office for community use
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS046
properties.notes: The SHELAA site (BAS046) benefits from permission in principle granted in October 2018 (18/02735/PIP). The site is currently being marketed and it is expected that there will be completions on site in the 6-10 year timeframe.. Residential development of 9 units. http:www.basingstoke.gov.uk/SHELAA
properties.ownership-status: not owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS054
properties.notes: The site has been promoted for development through the council's Call for Sites in 2019 by HCC. The site is considered to be potentially developable for 74 dwellings within a 5-10 year time period.
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS070
properties.notes: Consent was originally granted on the site (SHLAA Ref. BAS070) for the demolition of the Former Newman Bassett House building and a replacement smaller ‘respite unit’ has now been completed. (Hindson House).Therefore, this retains the facility and service use on the site and frees up the remainder of the land for residential redevelopment. The land is vacant and available and was promoted by HCC through the SHELAA for 12 units. However, given the current uncertainty with timescales for progressing the site and the level of suitable development, it has been placed in the 5-10 year time band for the purposes of land supply.. Residential development of 12 units. http:www.basingstoke.gov.uk/SHELAA
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority
properties.site-address: Land At Former Newman Bassett House Basingstoke

properties.name: BAS147
properties.notes: The site was promoted through the call for sites and lies within the built - up area of Basingstoke, within the SPB and within an area of predominantly residential development. the community use on the site has been unused for some time and the council, as landowner, is looking to redevelop the site in a suitable manner. any redevelopment of the site will need to provide sufficient evidence to demonstrate that due consideration has been given to the loss of the community use on the site.. Residential development of 6 units. http:www.basingstoke.gov.uk/SHELAA
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority
properties.site-address: Site Of Harlech Hall Harlech Close Winklebury Basingstoke

properties.name: BAS153
properties.notes: The regeneration of Basing View is being actively pursued by the borough council. This is reflected in Local Plan policy SS8 which supports the redevelopment of the area for a mix of uses including a residential component of approximately 300 units. The site is in a suitable location for housing development, lying in a highly accessible location with good access to public transport interchanges, town centre facilities and employment opportunities. The Council has commissioned BDP (Building Design Partnership) to prepare a Basing View Masterplan which will include focused work on areas with potential for residential development. The Council is committed to its delivery for a residential led scheme, however, as only part of the site is available now, the development has been placed outside of the 5 year timescale for the purposes of land supply. The site plan shows the whole of basing view reflecting the local plan allocation. The location of the residential element will be determined through site masterplanning.. Residential development of 300 units. http:www.basingstoke.gov.uk/SHELAA
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS184
properties.notes: The site is a SHELAA site which falls within the built up area of Basingstoke and within the SPB in an area of predominantly residential development in close proximity to the town. The current use as a police station is due to cease (as part of the wider review of Hampshire Constabulary sites) and is currently being marketed for redevelopment. As the site is not available now it has been placed in the 5-10 year time band.. Residential development of 30 units. http:www.basingstoke.gov.uk/SHELAA
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: BAS185
properties.notes: This SHELAA site is owned by a Housing Association, which is being reconsidered for residential development. The council has accepted, through a previous planning application on the site, that the loss of a care facility is acceptable in planning terms. The re-use of the site for residential development is therefore established. The site meets the developability tests, as set out in the NPPF.. Residential development of 12 units. http:www.basingstoke.gov.uk/SHELAA
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: BDB/54937
properties.notes: This site has a 5 year consent for 205 units (BDB54937). It is currently let for employment use. An extension of time application (BDB/76691) has been submitted and there is a resolution to grant subject to the legal agreement. There remains a reasonable prospect of the site being developed for residential purposes in the future, possibly as part of a more comprehensive development of Council owned land along Alencon Link. The site remains outside of the 5 year land supply as it fails to meet the deliverability tests set out in the NPPF in that the site is not available now.. Erection of 205 one and two bed flats with community rooms lettable space for A1,B1,D2 use
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: BDB/63103
properties.notes: The site is the remainder of a larger scheme for tied staff accommodation at Cheam Hawtreys School (BDB/63103, approved 2006). The school has confirmed, through the site monitoring consultation, that whilst the site will be delivered in due course, at present they have no intention to build out the remaining 6 units within the plan period. The site has therefore been phased beyond the plan period and its future delivery will continue to be reviewed through the annual monitoring process.
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: RO002
properties.notes: The site has been promoted for development through the council's Call for Sites in 2019 . The site is considered to be potentially developable for 21 dwellings within a 5-10 year time period.
properties.ownership-status: not owned by a public authority

properties.name: WHIT004
properties.notes: The site is allocated for approximately 15 dwellings in the Whitchurch Neighbourhood Plan (Policy HA1) which was made in October 2017 . The brownfield site is currently in use as a police station and is therefore not currently available. The Police Commissioners have confirmed that this site will cease to be used for its present purpose and will be available for housing development within the Plan Period which ends in 2029.
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority

properties.name: WHIT007
properties.notes: The site is allocated for approximately 10 dwellings in the Whitchurch Neighbourhood Plan (Policy HA3) which was made in October 2017 . The brownfield site is currently in use as a car centre and is therefore not currently available. However, the owners have confirmed their intention to redevelop the site for housings over the Local Plan period which runs to 2029.
properties.ownership-status: not owned by a public authority

properties.name: WHIT017
properties.notes: The site is allocated for approximately 15 dwellings in the Whitchurch Neighbourhood Plan (Policy HA1) which was made in October 2017 . The brownfield site is currently in use as a police station and is therefore not currently available. As such, it has been moved outside the 5 year land supply. The Police Commissioners have confirmed that this site will cease to be used for its present purpose and will be available for housing development within the Plan Period.. Housing development of 15 dwellings. http:www.basingstoke.gov.uk/SHELAA
properties.ownership-status: owned by a public authority
properties.site-address: Former Police Station Dances Lane Whitchurch
